head.title: Political Briefing; Assessing the Field, West Virginia-Style

hedline.hl1: Political Briefing; Assessing the Field, West Virginia-Style

abstract.p: Comments on controversy within West Virginia's Republican Party, stemming from comments by party chairman David Tyson that incumbent Democratic Sen Robert C Byrd, who has served seven six-year terms in US Senate, may be impossible to beat in November election (S)

block.p: There may be members of the United States Senate more entrenched than Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia. But surely not many. Mr. Byrd, a Democrat and exceptionally adroit procurer of political bacon, has won seven six-year terms, most by two to one or better, and the expectation is that he will win an eighth term this fall by at least that much.
So this is what David Tyson, the chairman of the West Virginia Republican Party, had to say last week when he was asked whether the party's primary on Tuesday might produce a viable Byrd challenger:

There may be members of the United States Senate more entrenched than Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia. But surely not many. Mr. Byrd, a Democrat and exceptionally adroit procurer of political bacon, has won seven six-year terms, most by two to one or better, and the expectation is that he will win an eighth term this fall by at least that much.
So this is what David Tyson, the chairman of the West Virginia Republican Party, had to say last week when he was asked whether the party's primary on Tuesday might produce a viable Byrd challenger:
''Running against Byrd is like running against an icon. Senator Byrd is an institution, and there's no denying that he could be impossible to beat.''
That, to use an old George Wallace political aphorism, was putting the hay down where the goat could get it.
One of the two primary contenders, Garry Adkins, an accountant, took umbrage. He accused Mr. Tyson of ''assisting a Democrat'' and demanded that the party remove him.
''I do not endorse Democrats. I support the Republican Party.''
No action, thus far, by the party and no complaint, thus far, from the other primary contender, David Gallaher, a businessman.
